page.title: 15 LOWER APPERLEY 3
page.content: The houses in Lower Apperley are spread out with large gardens or fields in between. This is called dispersed settlement. Most of the buildings seemed to be made of bricks with tile roofs, though some were of black and white half timber construction. Electricity did not arrive until the 1940's. The largest house lying in wooded grounds is Apperley Court. The farms lie on the edge of the spur of land close to the secondary road. In this way they have a mixture of drier arable fields and improved pasture on the slopes above the 10 metre contour and some water meadows below it. TO the north and below Apperley Court there is a wide drainage channel called Handkerchief Pool.
